newsitem.title: FRANCE: Russia takes step towards abolishing death penalty.
newsitem.headline: Russia takes step towards abolishing death penalty.

text.p: Russia took a step towards scrapping the death penalty on Wednesday by signing a European convention outlawing executions despite opposition from the Russian parliament.

The 40-nation Council of Europe, which admitted Russia as a member last year, said in a statement that Moscow had signed the protocol of the European Convention of Human Rights abolishing the death penalty in peacetime.
But Moscow's opposition-dominated parliament, which has ignored previous pleas by President Boris Yeltsin to scrap the death penalty, has to ratify the measure for it to become law.

Last month, the State Duma rejected a bill that would have formalised Russia's de facto suspension of the death penalty since 1996. Those favouring capital punishment point to a crime wave since the end of communist rule.

About 15 members of the Council of Europe, which aims to safeguard democracy and human rights across the continent, have yet to ratify the abolition of the death penalty, a theoretical duty of membership.
Among non-signers are Britain and Belgium.
